Years ago, I remember yelling at my CFO Dave Conte. He built a financial model that produced a higher revenue number than the previous one by adding more sales people earlier, but with no other changes. I said: “Goddammit, Dave, the spreadsheet is not the business!” My frustration came from the fact that there were so many other things that went into increasing the revenue to an exact number: the quality of the reps, the comprehensiveness of onboarding and training, the strength of the competitors, the quality of our sales enablement and marketing, the number of leads, and on and on.   It's not even close to being a success.
The same thing is true for Salesforce, which is a very simple and effective enterprise.  They can make a lot of money by having a small number of salespeople and a small number of lead people, for example.  I went to Salesforce for a few years, and I was always in search of potential leaders for my office and the sales team.  I tried to talk to them, but they never gave me any concrete ideas about how to grow the business.  I was worried what would happen if I tried to run a company that had a lot of leads and a lot of salespeople.  Then I realized that I should just be more creative and create a lot more salespeople.  I went back to the Salesforce office after I was fired.  I was doing the right thing, and I was now in a position where there was no reason to change my mind.

But there's a clear line between default living and dead, and when you default live, you're not going to be alive to start with. So to really understand what's going on, let's go back to the early days of human history.

Years ago, I remember yelling at my CFO Dave Conte. He built a financial model that produced a higher revenue number than the previous one by adding more sales people earlier, but with no other changes. I said: “Goddammit, Dave, the spreadsheet is not the business!” My frustration came from the fact that there were so many other things that went into increasing the revenue to an exact number: the quality of the reps, the comprehensiveness of onboarding and training, the strength of the competitors, the quality of our sales enablement and marketing, the number of leads, and on and on.   My frustration had led me to think that we needed a better sales manager.  We needed a better sales manager who was more proactive and would be more responsive to the needs of our customers.  Now, I know that the sales team that I hired was not one of the best.  They were all ineffective, and I was left with a situation where I could not find the right person to deliver.
It's been over 20 years and I still think that we had a good sales team.  I think we worked hard to create a good sales team, but we also had a good sales team that was not as innovative, and which we needed to be more responsive to.  We needed a better sales manager who would have a more responsive and more committed team.  I can only imagine how much we lost.  We did not have a good sales team.  We could not attract the right people.

phrase_40:
Years ago, I remember yelling at my CFO Dave Conte. He built a financial model that produced a higher revenue number than the previous one by adding more sales people earlier, but with no other changes. I said: “Goddammit, Dave, the spreadsheet is not the business!” My frustration came from the fact that there were so many other things that went into increasing the revenue to an exact number: the quality of the reps, the comprehensiveness of onboarding and training, the strength of the competitors, the quality of our sales enablement and marketing, the number of leads, and on and on.   We had a lot of other things in our plan but we didn't get the money.
That day, I went back to the office, and asked Conte if the plan worked.
What happened was that I began to feel like I had a problem. I had a problem with the marketing. I had a problem with the sales. I had a problem with the relationships between the staff and the customer. I had a problem with the customer and the sales staff.  I felt like I had worked really hard, and I was getting a lot of work done.
When Conte was done, I asked him to fix what was broken, and he said: ‪Goddammit, I'm leaving.”
And so I did, and I left.  But I did not feel as though I was the only one who felt like I had a problem.
